title: Repossessions fall to historic low as home owners keep on top of their mortgages
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Aug 13, 2015, 14:02 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 28 mins Repossessions fall to historic low as home owners keep on top of their mortgages By Tim Wallace | Telegraph â€“ 21 minutes ago Print 
Low interest rates have helped homeowners pay their mortgages and keep their properties 
Repossessions fell to the lowest level ever as more families and landlords stayed on top of their mortgage payments in the second quarter of the year. 
Low interest rates were a key factor in reducing debt problems, while the economic recovery with relatively low unemployment and rising wages also helped. 
The three-month period saw 2,500 properties taken into possession by lenders, down from 3,000 in the previous quarter and from 5,400 in the second quarter of 2014. 
By contrast, in 2009, 48,900 homes were repossessed, averaging more than 12,000 per quarter, according to the data from the Council of Mortgage Lenders. 
The latest figures translate to a repossession rate of 0.02pc, or one property in every 5,000. 
Of the 2,000 homes repossessed in the second quarter, 1,800 were owner-occupied and 700 were buy-to-let properties. 
At the same time the number of borrowers who were behind on their mortgage payments is also at a record low. 
The CML said that 106,400 borrowers had arrears amounting to more than 2.5pc of the mortgage balance in the second quarter, the lowest figure since the industry's quarterly data series began in 2008. 
Of those in arrears 100,700 were owner-occupiers, and 5,700 buy-to-let borrowers. A total of 20,800 had arrears of between 5pc and 7.5pc of their mortgage balance, while 10,300 were overdue on payments amounting to between 7.5pc and 10pc, while a further 23,400 had arrears of more than 10pc. 
"Across all measures, mortgage arrears and repossessions are continuing to improve. We continue to see some amplification of the downward trend in repossessions, which may bring into question our repossessions forecast for 2015 as a whole," said the CML's director general Paul Smee. 
"This trend is very welcome. Low interest rates are acting as a significant support for home owners in general, and are likely to be helping to stave off low-level arrears for stretched households in particular." 
The figures come as increasing numbers of homeowners are remortgaging their properties in an effort to lock in low interest rates before the Bank of England decides to start making borrowing more expensive .
